Belson is a Sports Reporter covering National Professional Football for The New York Times, as well as the Business of Sports. [CR-LF][CR-LF]He focuses on players, teams and leagues from a broad business perspective. He also covers the companies that try to capitalize on the sports industry. As for the topics that interest him, he says, "The quirkier the better."[CR-LF][CR-LF]He is looking for consumer-oriented items. He recommends that PR professionals "frame the story to show the consumer link. The quicker you can frame your business opportunity in terms of consumers, the more it will help me."[CR-LF][CR-LF]He doesn't always need an exclusive, but appreciates when PR professionals are upfront. He urges PR professionals to "Be straightforward. Solve the problem." By presenting the fact that the competition has already covered the story, he can be prepared and approach the topic differently. But if he has to find out on his own, he "definitely won’t use it."[CR-LF][CR-LF]He prefers to be contacted by email around 9am ET. If he must be contacted by phone, call in the morning as well. He does NOT want to receive follow-up calls. "They're annoying," he says. "I get too many press releases to have everybody calling making sure I got them. Sometimes it takes me a month to get back to people."[CR-LF][CR-LF]"I read all my email. Sometimes I'll keep something and call someone on it. For those people that are looking for instant gratification, I'm more likely to throw those stories out." However, he's "very open to stuff. I like to talk to people … but make sure you think about the pitch and what I need."[CR-LF][CR-LF]With regard to his coverage, Belson says, "I cover the NFL, and specifically the business of the NFL. Read the stories I write. If you don't have the time to read them, then I won't take you seriously. Personalize the pitch. If I see an email that starts with "Hi there" it will be quickly deleted. If you pitch me on baseball, triathlon, tennis, boxing or other sports, I'm will likely delete your email. No need to call me if you have already emailed me. I read every email I receive and if you haven't heard from me, it is because I am busy or not interested."[CR-LF] [CR-LF]He adds that, "Some stories take months to complete, especially feature stories and stories that are pitched out of season but need to run in season. Brown serves as weekend anchor and reporter during the week.[CR-LF][CR-LF]Brown joined WRAL-TV on August 25, 2014 as a weekend anchor and reporter. She last worked at WCBS-TV since January 2010. She was formerly a correspondent with CBS Newspath since June 2008. She was previously a general assignment reporter at WJZ-TV since 2005. She previously served as a reporter and fill-in anchor at WSET-TV in Roanoke, VA. Prior to that, she worked at the assignment desk at WABC-TV in New York City. She also was an anchor and reporter for NewSource 15, a CNN affiliate based near Atlanta. Before entering the broadcast arena, she spent several years working in politics, including the Governor of Georgia’s press office.[CR-LF][CR-LF]Brown has covered numerous stories throughout her career. She received kudos for her extensive coverage of the murder of a 12 year old girl, a story that rocked Virginia and garnered national headlines under the banner the Amber Alert. She also traveled to Florida to cover the aftermath of hurricanes Frances and Ivan. Brown graduated with bachelor's degrees in broadcast news and political science from the University of Georgia.

Lynnley will working in the tax & accounting team based in New York. Nanette Byrnes has also be joined the tax & accounting team. Nanette previously reported for BusinessWeek, where she won several awards, including the Loeb award for financial journalism in 2002. Contact Profile: Dano is the Editor-in-Chief for the Telecom Group of FierceMarkets, which includes FierceWirelessTech, FierceWireless, FierceTelecom, FierceCable, FierceBroadcasting and FierceInstaller. He likes to receive press releases and information on new products and breaking news in this area. "I'd rather get everything and delete what I don't need," he said. He advises PR professionals to be straightforward with their pitches. He said, "One of the main skills you develop in B2B is seeing through the hype. If there is something interesting you are writing about, just know that and express it clearly and concisely. Do not try to tie it to something that is irrelevant." He added, "We definitely want to see everything that is out there so that we can make informative judgments about what to bring to our readers." He warns publicists that because the site is driven by major news events, they rarely will act on a pitch. Avoid sending local pitches. He prefers to be contacted by e-mail and said, "I read all of the e-mails I get. If you send me an e-mail I will read it." Press material related to law firms and law business can be sent to him. Regarding PR contact, Reilly explains: "A quirk of our paper is that we don't follow the daily competition (Star Tribune, Pioneer Press) on stories. This generally means most press releases aren't very useful to us, aside from using us for a brief on our Web site. This can cause problems, as PR pros sometimes don't understand this, and get disappointed when we don't bite on a news release. This isn't necessarily a peeve, it's just something that happens."
